feedback: Qualcomm welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the European Commissions Call for Evidence on the review of the Chips Act and supports the development of a more ambitious, innovation-driven Chips Act 2. The current Chips Act mobilized political attention and major investment, establishing semiconductors as a strategic priority for Europe. Yet implementation has revealed structural limitations that have to be addressed to strengthen Europes competitiveness, resilience, and technological sovereignty. The current focus on reaching 20% global manufacturing capacity by 2030 has generated momentum but is unlikely to be met. Therefore, Europe should therefore complement production goals with innovation-oriented indicators, including design capability, R&D intensity, advanced packaging, IP generation, skilled workforce development, and leadership in AI, 5G/6G, edge computing and energy-efficient low-power processing. A key limitation of the existing framework is its emphasis on large-scale fabs. Europe has under-supported vital segments such as chip design, IP, EDA tools, advanced packaging, materials, equipment, and fabless companies. These areas are essential for technological sovereignty and represent domains where Europe can achieve global leadership. SMEs and start-ups, which drive much of semiconductor design innovation, face administrative barriers and limited access to funding and foundry capacity. Chips Act 2 should therefore broaden eligibility, simplify procedures, and ensure predictable access to manufacturing through structured public-private partnerships. To remain competitive, Europe must also address structural enablers: deployment of skilled engineers, affordable clean energy, reliable water, and critical raw materials. A dedicated European semiconductor skills programme is needed, including investment in STEM education, international mobility schemes, and collaborative research exchanges with trusted industrial partners. Stronger governance and coordination are essential for efficiency and impact. The role of the European Semiconductor Board should be reinforced, enabling it to coordinate strategy, permitting, and funding at EU level. A one-stop-shop for project approval would reduce fragmentation and increase legal certainty. Greater transparency of funding flows and outcomes is necessary to avoid duplication and ensure effective allocation of public resources. Qualcomm emphasizes the strategic importance of strengthening European chip design capabilities. Supporting open and secure design frameworks, including the RISC-V instruction set architecture, can reduce dependency on proprietary technologies and stimulate innovation, particularly in automotive, industrial, robotics, AI, and edge applications. Chips Act 2 should be integrated with Europes broader digital and industrial strategies, including AI, advanced connectivity, quantum technologies, sustainable digitalization and the green transition. Semiconductors underpin Europes ability to lead in these domains. A more holistic approach linking research, design, industrial deployment and cross-sector application would create stronger synergies and reinforce Europes global position. Qualcomm supports the strategic objectives set out by the Semicon Coalitionprosperity, indispensability, and resilienceand the alignment of national initiatives with EU-level instruments. Europe should measure success not only through manufacturing share, but through leadership in design, IP, specialized technologies, trusted supply chains, and sustainable semiconductor development. A future-proof Chips Act 2 should create a coherent, innovation-centred policy architecture that strengthens Europes position across the full semiconductor value chainfrom conception and design to deploymentwhile fostering open standards, trusted partnerships and long-term competitiveness.

feedback: The documents present coordinated feedback from the Spanish semiconductor ecosystem for the revision of the Chips Act 2.0. The main message is the need for a more operational, flexible, and industry-aligned framework that accelerates design, prototyping, manufacturing access, and market deployment. The ecosystem stresses that Europe must strengthen the fabless model, which represents most Spanish companies, by improving access to open EDA tools, shared tape-outs, certification support, and private-public financing instruments. Existing aid schemes are viewed as too rigid, slow, and uneven across Member States; the proposal calls for simpler procedures, predictable deadlines, direct support to design centers and equipment suppliers, and a sovereignty seal to fast-track strategic projects. Talent is described as one of the biggest bottlenecks, requiring a European micro-credential system, mobility programs, and coordinated training pathways. The documents also insist on better alignment between the Chips Act and the Critical Raw Materials Act, recognizing gases, chemicals, and equipment suppliers as priority actors. Demand-side incentives are considered essential to create scale, especially in automotive, energy, defense, telecom, and health. The annex provides sector-specific recommendations: in telecoms, advancing RF, chiplets, and 5G/6G SoCs; in defense and space, secure and radiation-resistant chips and flexible Lab-to-Fab prototyping; in AI hardware, promoting RISC-V, neuromorphic systems, open design, and green chips; in photonics, positioning it as a strategic enabling technology with shared pilot lines; in materials, boosting European production of chemicals, 2D materials, and equipment, and promoting circularity; in automotive, validating EU-made chips and integrating European sensors; and in energy, supporting SiC/GaN, efficient power conversion chips, and greener manufacturing. Overall, the feedback emphasizes practical mechanisms, stronger governance with industry participation, and the need to turn strategic priorities into concrete, enforceable operational tools.

feedback: Europes semiconductor strategy must avoid the risk of directing most public funding toward large industrial actors while neglecting the foundational layers of the ecosystem, i.e. design tools, early-stage research infrastructure, and the skills pipeline. Providing funds to industry without strengthening the toolchain is dangerous, especially considering that nearly all critical Electronic Design Automation (EDA), verification, and cloud-based design environments are controlled by non-EU companies. If Europe rebuilds manufacturing capacity on top of external, licensed, and often opaque toolflows, it will remain strategically dependent even after investing billions in fabrication capacity. The chips ecosystem also needs greater diversity across application domains. Current policy often emphasises automotive, industrial controllers, or legacy embedded markets, but long-term competitiveness requires support for specialised chips in areas where Europe already has strong scientific and industrial depth, such as edge AI, telecommunications, biomedical systems, secure IoT, and energy-efficient AI accelerators. A crucial part of enabling this diversification is strengthening rapid prototyping and early-stage technology evaluation before fabrication. Academic research can make major contributions here yet is currently under supported. In parallel, hardware security must be elevated to a core objective of the Chips Act. The frequency of hardware-level attacks, trojans, and supply-chain compromises is rising sharply, and modern systems depend on secure-by-design components at all abstraction levels, from circuits to packaging to system integration. Without substantial investment in research on hardware assurance, open and transparent verification platforms, security-oriented design methodologies, and trusted test infrastructures, Europe risks creating advanced chipmaking capacity that is still vulnerable to manipulation, counterfeits, and external control points embedded in the toolchain. Finally, true security of supply cannot be achieved through factories alone. A resilient semiconductor ecosystem requires sovereign capability in design, modelling, verification, packaging, testing, and system-level integration. Strengthening shared research facilities, open-source tool development, and training programmes will ensure that European engineers, SMEs, and universities can participate in the full semiconductor value chain. Balancing industrial subsidies with investments in tools, talent, and hardware security is the only sustainable path to real technological sovereignty and long-term supply-chain resilience for Europe.

feedback: Europe's semiconductor strategy should shift from pursuing manufacturing autonomy to becoming an irreplaceable partner in the global value chain. The 2023 Act's ambition to reach 20% of global chip production was a reasonable response to the supply chain disruptions of 2020-2022, but the threat landscape has fundamentally changed. With targets increasingly out of reach and the required investment prohibitively large, Europe cannot win a subsidy race against the US and China. More importantly, chip access is now threatened predominantly by deliberate geopolitical restrictions rather than accidental disruptions. A strategy built around manufacturing capacity cannot address a world where semiconductors have become instruments of economic leverage. Europe must adapt accordingly. Strategic indispensability offers a more effective path. Europe already holds critical chokepoints in the global supply chain. By ensuring the global supply chain remains dependent on European technology, the EU ensures that partners and rivals alike have a strategic interest in maintaining Europe's access to their chipssecuring access to all advanced chip types, not just those a European fab might produce. Achieving this requires three reinforcing capabilities: comprehensive dependency mapping, targeted investment in high-leverage technologies, and stronger coordination for a credible European response when chip access is threatened. These efforts will be more likely to succeed if embedded within the broader competitiveness reforms recommended in the Draghi and Letta reports, from capital-market integration to regulatory reform. I. Better Situational Awareness. The Commission should map bidirectional dependencies, identifying not only where Europe is vulnerable, but also where the global supply chain depends on European technology. This requires mandatory data provision from key market actors and greatly increased technical capacity at the Commission. II. Clearer Strategy. Replace the 20% volume target with a strategic portfolio approach: protect existing strengths in lithography equipment (ASML), precision optics (Zeiss), and research infrastructure (imec); back emerging technologies where Europe can establish future leverage; and reduce critical dependencies selectively, focusing on automotive and edge inference chips rather than comprehensive manufacturing autonomy. The revised Act should establish a Strategic Semiconductor Asset designation for entities at critical chokepoints, triggering tailored support including extended state-aid flexibility, STEP integration, fast-track permitting, and streamlined communication with the Commission. III. Stronger Coordination. Europe's fragmented export control governance leaves individual Member States vulnerable to external pressure. The revised Act should coordinate export control decisions at EU level and develop a calibrated response framework; a menu of retaliatory measures that Europe could deploy if third countries restrict Europes access to chips. This provides credible deterrence without immediate escalation. The revised Act should also establish a streamlined response mechanism with pre-approved triggers, accelerated timelines, and a solidarity fund for companies affected by export controls.

feedback: The EU Chips Act 2.0 offers the opportunity for a decisive turning point in the European semiconductor industry and technology policy. While the first Chips Act focused primarily on resilience and security of supply at a time of acute supply bottlenecks, Europe now needs a semiconductor policy that focuses on technological leadership, competitive strength, and indispensability in the value chain through innovative power. The focus must shift from reactive crisis management to a long-term location strategy. The revision of the EU Chips Act offers a unique opportunity to secure Europe's technological sovereignty, economic resilience, and industrial competitiveness. Europe has outstanding research, strong user industries, and clusters, but it lacks speed, coordina-tion, and investment momentum. Other regions of the world are acting more strategically and cohesively, while European procedures are still too fragmented and bureaucratic. The Chips Act 2.0 must draw conclusions from this: less complexity, more impact. An industrial policy approach that views research, development, and manufacturing as an integrated value chain is crucial. Taking into account the budget situation and priorities in financial planning, public funding should be targeted at areas where Europe can build indispensable competencies and receive the right impetus with the help of this funding. These include, above all, areas such as power semiconductors, chip design, AI and quantum chips, and future technologies such as Edge AI. The strong supply industry is also a key success factor for the European semiconductor ecosystem. In addition, the future technology of photonics should be highlighted as a strategically relevant field. At the same time, it is important to accelerate knowledge transfer between research and industry and to integrate start-ups and SMEs into the innovation ecosystem. European semiconductor policy must not isolate itself in this regard. Resilience comes from international networking with trustworthy partners, not from isolation. Strategic cooperation with countries such as Japan, South Korea, and Singapore can stabilize supply chains, create common standards, and secure access to technologies. Equally important is strengthening the conditions in Europe: competitive energy prices, reliable framework conditions, modern infrastructure, reliable access to critical raw materials, and a determined reduction of regulatory hurdles. The EU Chips Act 2.0 can only be successful if, at the same time, the conditions mentioned above are significantly improved. The Chips Act 2.0 can only be effective if the industry is able to help shape it as a partner. What Europe needs now is a clear strategic vision that recognizes semiconductors as a crucial factor in the resilience of the economy, society, and technological sovereignty, and that consistently anchors the aforementioned principles in its implementation.

feedback: A broadened scope beyond the current logic centric Chips Act would allow other semiconductor technologies to benefit from incentives and create a more complete European ecosystem. Today, the Act focuses primarily on advanced logic nodes leaving critical gaps in areas where Europe has strong research capabilities and strategic needs. Expanding the scope would strengthen resilience and reduce dependency on non-European suppliers. Examples of additional areas include advanced display technologies such as MicroLEDs and AR/VR which are essential for next generation automotive, medical and immersive applications. Without targeted support, Europe risks losing ground to Asia where aggressive national strategies are accelerating commercialization. Optical interconnects for AI servers represent another key area enabling ultra-high bandwidth and low latency while reducing energy consumption in data centers which is a priority as AI workloads grow. Sensing technologies are equally important for automotive safety, industrial automation and healthcare. Wide bandgap materials (WBG) such as SiC and GaN are crucial for power electronics in electric vehicles, renewable energy systems and RF applications for telecom. These materials enable higher efficiency and lower energy loss, thus directly supporting EU climate targets. Both microLEDs and WBG materials support the Green Deal. Additionally, equipment manufacturing such as epitaxy reactors and laser transfer systems must be developed within Europe to reduce dependency on foreign toolmakers and secure supply chains. Incentives in these areas will unlock high value applications aligned with EU digital and green transition goals. MicroLEDs offer low power consumption and long lifespan supporting sustainability and energy efficiency. Wide bandgap semiconductors are indispensable for EV fast charging renewable energy integration and telecom infrastructure. Domestic equipment capability ensures Europe can maintain autonomy in critical manufacturing processes. A Chips Act 2.0 should include strategies directed at specific technology areas where European research is at the forefront. Taiwans action plan for display technologies provides a strong role model demonstrating how targeted policies accelerate commercialization. Public procurement mandates should be employed to create demand for European components in EU funded projects, particularly for the defense industry where independent supply chains are critical. Incentives for large enterprises to source components from European SMEs will help create an environment where the transition from mainly VC-funded to mainly-revenue funded models becomes easier. To build on Europes semiconductor start-up base, effective piloting services must be available for SMEs to encourage scaling within the EU. Cost barriers for access to shared cleanrooms and bonding facilities should be reduced. Programs focusing on the transition from lab-to-fab to reach volume production need to be prioritized, including display technologies. Funding for yield optimization during the scaling phase can bridge the gap between a first launch of an MVP and commercial scale production. Finally, specialized pan-European training programs for new talent and reskilling are necessary to address skill shortages. Funding options at the EU level without mandatory national co-funding should be created to ensure broader participation and faster deployment. The here listed actions and programs would greatly improve the likelihood of successfully taking the excellent European research to commercialization, something that today is a major weakness in Europe compared to Asian and American ecosystems.

feedback: CLEPA welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the review of the European Chips Act. While the Chips Act represents an important step forward, several gaps remain in bridging the distance between research and industrial deployment, strengthening backend manufacturing capabilities, and enabling a complete, efficient value chain that reflects the needs of Europes automotive and industrial ecosystems. Pillar I The Chips for Europe Initiative Pillar I provides important research capabilities, but it does not yet generate the support required for the technologies and developments needed to enable industrial-scale deployment for the automotive industry. At present, no clear pipeline exists between what is developed in Pillar I and what should be manufactured in future European facilities. To be effective, Pillar I must translate development programmes into producible technologies and directly address the requirements of European downstream industries as the automotive industry. The Chips Act 2 and its research and development arm should be designed with end-user needs in mind and must contribute to future capacity guarantees, helping to correct the current imbalance between strong European automotive demand and limited regional production options. Pillar II Security of supply and resilience Pillar IIs scope remains narrowly focused on frontend fabs. While backend processes are formally included, current investments in backend remain limited because the European backend manufacturing sector is not competitive, leaving critical capacity gaps unaddressed. Operational expenditure support for backend activities is essential to enable industrial-scale deployment and ensure that Europe can meet automotive and broader industrial demand. To achieve this, a targeted revision of state aid rules should be envisaged, allowing OPEX support for specific segments of the supply chain, for example for backend operations, advanced packaging, testing, and assembly, while ensuring that funding remains efficient and focused. Beyond addressing backend, structural weaknesses (i.e. high energy costs, administrative burdens, permitting delays, and skill shortages) must be tackled to make Europe a competitive and reliable location for semiconductor production. Investments should strengthen the full automotive semiconductor ecosystem. EU-level coordination is critical to prevent fragmentation across Member States, and design/fabless companies as well as upstream suppliers should be fully integrated into the security-of-supply framework. Finally, the status and incentives of production facilities should be aligned with actual market needs and the requirements of full-value-chain integration. Pillar III Monitoring and crisis response Pillar III establishes monitoring and crisis response mechanisms, but its current approach is largely reactive and narrowly focused on semiconductor supply data. Existing tools rely heavily on static databases rather than real-time dialogue, which limits the EUs ability to anticipate geopolitical risks, export controls, or supply chain disruptions. System-level vulnerabilities in the automotive sector are insufficiently addressed, and governance does not fully integrate end-user industries or industrialisation challenges. Pillar III should replace passive data collection with proactive, continuous dialogue between industry and the Commission. Geopolitical risks, export controls, logistics, and bottlenecks should be monitored in real time, and the entire automotive ecosystem should be involved in crisis monitoring. Clear and predictable early-warning indicators should be established, focusing on non-substitutable components and geopolitical triggers. EU-level coordination is needed to prevent fragmented national responses, and crisis preparedness should consider industrialisation and market uptake bottlenecks, not only raw supply constraints.

feedback: My feedback reflects the perspective of a semiconductor start-up developing wide-spectrum image sensors for high-volume computer-vision applications. Our work focuses primarily on groundbreaking process technologies based on novel quantum materials. While the Chips Act is an important and timely initiative, it appears to be oriented mainly toward large companies and academic institutions. Historically, SMEs have played a crucial role in the European semiconductor and deep-tech landscape, yet their needs seem insufficiently considered in the design of current funding schemes. In my view, Europe will capture the greatest future value by investing in genuinely groundbreaking technologies. Part of that investment should indeed support academia and research institutes, but start-ups and spin-offs are equally vital. They are the engines that translate scientific breakthroughs into market-ready technologies. The Chips Act starts now supporting design-focused start-ups, while those working on novel process technologiessuch as ours do not seem to be taken into account when evaluating the current and future relevant funding instruments. In our specific case, no suitable calls for collaborative projects were available. The EIC Accelerator call for semiconductor technologies opened only once, and unfortunately at a time when we were not yet ready to apply. We believe this represents a missed opportunity, especially at a moment when technological sovereignty is so critical for Europe. Designers can be attracted abroad relatively easily. In contrast, infrastructure, process know-how, and manufacturing capabilities rooted in Europe are far harder to relocate. Europe does not need to compete exclusively on the most advanced CMOS nodes. Instead, it should invest now in diverse, innovative process technologies that will form the foundation of tomorrows semiconductor landscape. One of the most effective ways to do this is by supporting start-ups and spin-offs working on disruptive process technologies.

feedback: Europe is strategically prioritizing semiconductor and quantum technologies to bolster its industrial competitiveness and technological sovereignty, in line with the Chips Act. Success will depend on leveraging existing strengths in areas like cryogenics, photonics, control electronics and specialized manufacturing, alongside increased investment in quantum-specific fabrication capabilities and dedicated pilot lines. Key challenges include transitioning from flexible R&D facilities to high-volume manufacturing, integrating quantum process design kits (PDKs) to standardize production workflows, and addressing the unique fabrication requirements of quantum processors potentially requiring dedicated or repurposed foundries and shared infrastructure models. To accelerate iteration cycles, retain strategic IP and create local industrial value, the Chips Act 2.0 should incorporate mechanisms that provide quantum companies with small-scale, in-house prototyping and fabrication pathways in addition to open foundry access. To maintain a leading position, Europe must also balance open global collaboration with the need for technological autonomy. This requires a nuanced, risk-based approach to partnerships, avoiding overly restrictive policies that could stifle innovation or discourage investment, while safeguarding critical capabilities and securing access to essential raw materials. Crucially, scaling quantum technologies demands a fully supported value chain from design and fabrication to testing and packaging alongside stronger cross-sector coordination between semiconductor, quantum and HPC industries. A collaborative, risk-based approach will be vital for fostering a competitive and resilient European quantum ecosystem. Suggested actions/Policy option 1. Make Quantum Chips a core pillar of Chips Act 2.0, with increased funding for pilot lines, enabling technologies, and quantum-specific manufacturing and testing capacity. 2. Support small-scale in-house prototyping facilities that can accelerate design iteration and IP retention, while still enabling controlled access for scientific communities under appropriate agreements. 3. Create flexible, industry-oriented funding instruments to support design, prototyping, fabrication and testing of quantum-enabling integrated circuits leveraging existing semiconductor value chain to reinforce the robustness of the quantum supply chain. 4. Adopt a risk-based international partnership framework, enabling cooperation with trusted allies while ensuring security of critical materials and technologies. 5. Support manufacturing and test infrastructure for all quantum modalities, considering areas where Europe already shows early commercial traction.

feedback: The first EU Chips Act has shifted Europes position in the global semiconductor landscape. It delivered long-needed political momentum and enabled the first concrete steps toward rebuilding advanced fabrication capacity, notably through the creation of the European Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (ESMC) by Infineon, NXP, Bosch and TSMC. Yet these measures remain insufficient for reaching the EUs 20% market-share target by 2028 or for ensuring long-term resilience. Several private-sector initiatives have already been delayed or reduced, including Intels projects in France and Germany, uncertainty around STMicroelectronics future footprint, and the gradual loss of legacy production such as NXPs Nijmegen line. These developments underline the fragility of the European ecosystem. A central difficulty is that, unlike aircraft manufacturingwhere the Airbus model succeeded because it produced a standardized, certifiable product with predictable demandsemiconductors do not benefit from stable, uniform market structures. Products differ widely across applications and evolve on short timescales. Simply providing fabrication capacity does not ensure that it will be used. Demand must be deliberately created; otherwise, the facilities established under Chips Act 1 risk underutilization. Chips Act 2.0 must therefore address both supply and demand in a coordinated manner. In this context, the University of Zurich proposes actions to better align research, infrastructure and industrial activity. A key element is the introduction of regular multi-project wafer (MPW) runs at mature nodes within ESMC. Although the planned 1210 nm capability is strategically valuable, much of Europes applied research and industrial electronics still relies on 135, 80, 65 and 28 nm technologies. Quarterly MPW runs supported by open or semi-open PDKs would enable universities, SMEs and research groups to design and prototype domestically. Publicly funded research projects involving IC design should, when technically feasible, be expected to use European manufacturing infrastructure to reinforce this pipeline and create predictable baseline demand. A longer-term objective is to strengthen Europes supply chain, including wafer production, post-processing, packaging and testing. Europe does not need to replicate the dense Asian fab clusters; a coordinated, distributed model is possible, but only if policy actively shapes demand through procurement commitments and targeted incentives. Zero-cost MPW access for open-PDK designs would reduce financial barriers and encourage domestic prototyping. feedback: Water Europe (WE) supports the European Commissions evaluation of the EU Chips Act 2.0. Given the strategic role of semiconductors in Europes digitalisation, energy transition and industrial competitiveness, the revision of the Chips Act offers a unique opportunity to address all critical enablers of chip manufacturing. Yet, despite the recognised focus on energy efficiency and circularity, the current evaluation neglects water which is a fundamental resource of the value chain. Water is indispensable for semiconductor production. Today, the EU produces 3 million wafers per month, consuming 45 million m³ of freshwater - 15 m³ per 12-inch wafer. Advanced memory chips can require up to 21 litres of water per cm². Doubling production to 6 million wafers monthly by 2030 would raise water demand to between 72 and 108 million m³ per month, a 60-140% increase. Fab processes require ultra-pure water (UPW), with each wafer being rinsed around 100 times. Producing 1 litre of UPW requires 1.5 litres of freshwater, and impurities (even microscopic) can ruin chips and reduce yield. Water scarcity directly threatens manufacturing continuity. The 2021 Taiwanese drought forced major plants to limit operations, doubling global chip lead times and generating estimated EU-wide losses of around 27.5 million per month. At the same time, semiconductor production generates chemically loaded wastewater; by 2030, EU plants could discharge 1450 million m³ annually depending on recycling performance. Advanced water technologies therefore represent not only an environmental requirement but also a competitive lever. While global leaders recycle up to 86% of their process water, EU manufacturers average just 45%. Raising European recycling rates and deploying state-of-the-art purification solutions could reduce freshwater abstraction by 216 million m³ yearly and generate savings exceeding 1 billion. Because semiconductor policy objectives directly depend on secure and efficient water use, the Chips Act must explicitly integrate water management into its strategic framework, in line with the objective to build a water-smart economy. Achieving leading-edge manufacturing (sub-10nm) will require more sophisticated UPW systems. Improving Europes competitiveness hinges on reducing environmental and operational costs through advanced water reuse, while supply chain resilience cannot be ensured without assessing water availability and treatment capacity. Water Europe recommends: 1.Recognise water infrastructure and technologies as essential enablers, and water companies as partners in EU policy-making, for achieving EU semiconductor production goals and strategic autonomy. 2.Enable access to Chips Act funding for water purification, recycling, and wastewater treatment infrastructure specifically tailored to semiconductor manufacturing requirements. 3.Promote adoption of advanced water management technologies, best practices, guidelines and common water performance indicators to improve competitiveness, circularity and water efficiency in semiconductor production. 4.Integrate considerations on water resources in supply chain resilience assessments and permit requirements for semiconductor production. 5.Support partnerships and knowledge exchange platforms between semiconductor manufacturers, water technology providers, and regional water authorities to address water challenges. Water security is a structural pillar of semiconductor manufacturing . To build a resilient, competitive and sustainable chip ecosystem, the EU Chips Act 2.0 must embed water at its core.

feedback: Les composants semiconducteurs constituent aujourdhui des intrants essentiels de la plupart des autres industries, nécessaires à leurs fonctionnalités électroniques, et constituent le vecteur de la maîtrise de lespace numérique. Aussi, sans recherche dune indépendance stratégique dans le domaine, lEurope ne pourra poursuivre sans risques majeurs ses ambitions de prospérité et de liberté pour ses citoyens. Le CEA souligne limportance de poursuivre la stratégie de lEurope en matière de renforcement de sa base technologique et industrielle en semiconducteur sur la durée, dune part en capitalisant sur les avancées obtenues, et dautre part en adaptant la stratégie et les actions aux enseignements des deux premières années du Chips Act et aux évolutions du contexte économique et géopolitique. Concernant les avancées obtenues, le Pilier 1 du Chips Act a considérablement renforcé en Europe les capacités dinnovation et de transferts de technologies vers lindustrie, en établissant une stratégie dinvestissement coordonnée à léchelle de lUnion Européenne dans des infrastructures de masse critique ouvertes vers la communauté académique et les entreprises européennes. La poursuite dune telle stratégie de mutualisation des moyens des acteurs européens dans des infrastructures technologiques, quelle soit en matière de lignes pilotes de technologie semiconducteur ou bien denvironnement de conception, constitue un élément structurant pour le succès de la stratégie européenne. Lexploitation des investissements installés dans le cadre des lignes pilotes mérite dêtre poursuivie au-delà des programmes de R&D ayant présidé à leur lancement, en portant de nouveaux programmes de R&D de technologies de rupture. Ce volet amont gagnerait à être complété par un mécanisme de financement de laccès aux capacités des lignes pilotes pour les acteurs de la recherche académique européen pour accroître linclusion des communautés au-delà des organismes porteurs. Le transfert industriel des résultats dinnovation de ces lignes pilotes, quil soit vers des sites industriels existants ou la création de nouveaux acteurs pour la mise en place dusines « first of a kind », constitue le marqueur de succès de la stratégie du Chips Act. Ce succès repose sur la collaboration entre lindustrie, les acteurs des lignes pilotes et les fabless sappuyant sur linfrastructure de conception, au travers de projets soutenus par la Commission Européenne et les Etats Membres. En conséquence, le pilier 2 du Chips Act pourrait être revu pour permettre le financement direct par la Commission Européenne des actions de première industrialisation portées par les IPCEI ou de production de masse dindustrie « first of a kind ». Dans la compétition mondiale, lEurope fait face à des écosystèmes industriels appuyés sur de vastes marchés intérieurs et des politiques publiques structurées de lamont à laval de la chaine de valeur. Lagrégation de la demande au sein de lUnion peut constituer un puissant levier de soutien à lindustrie des semiconducteurs européenne. Il pourrait faire sens dintroduire dans les commandes publiques un recours à un contenu important en matière de semiconducteurs européens, et de stimuler lécosystème en investissant dans des infrastructures critiques européennes, telles que les réseaux de télécommunication terrestres et spatiaux, terminaux de communications équipant les forces armées et la sécurité civile, les infrastructures de calcul, les moyens de surveillance du territoire

feedback: We submit this contribution as authors of the attached document The European Reference Fab Executive Summary with Q&A Annex. The underlying concept The Transparent Reference Fab Blueprint for a Trustworthy and Transparent Manufacturing Network is deliberately published as an open blueprint so that stakeholders can scrutinise, reuse and adapt it in the context of Chips Act 2. The Transparent Reference Fab (TRF) is a proposal for a standardised, cloneable 300-mm reference fab at mature nodes (13065 nm) that provides trustworthy, auditable manufacturing capacity for security- and safety-critical chips and systems as shared European manufacturing infrastructure. It is the reference environment in which auditable & trustworthy dies and systems are manufactured. Clone sites can be deployed in a modular way as front-end lines, assembly/test hubs or combined facilities and can be scaled and specialised to match national, industrial and sectoral needs. The TRF combines front-end processing, test and advanced assembly into a single, governed infrastructure asset, with open design enablement so that industry, SMEs, start-ups and research actors can actually use this capacity. Cloning is enabled due to the transparent blueprint documentation. By hosting chiplet-aware design plus final system integration and test, the TRF turns external leading-edge compute dies into trustworthy systems, creating a systematic bridge to leading-edge nodes while keeping the final system-level trust anchor preferably via auditable trust-anchor dies manufactured in the TRF in Europe. Consultation contributions and our stakeholder discussions highlight four structural gaps that TRF directly addresses: 1. Mature-node sovereignty for long-lifecycle, security-relevant electronics. Europe still lacks dependable mature-node capacity, even though these nodes underpin critical infrastructure, industry and defence. TRF focuses on this mission and enables co-integration with leading-edge nodes: compute dies can be sourced globally but are only combined, tested and qualified in a trustworthy TRF environment, anchored by trust-anchor dies made in Europe. 2. A system view across front-end, assembly and board-level integration. Front-end investments are insufficient if assembly, test and board-level integration remain offshore. TRF turns these elements into one governed, traceable chain instead of separate projects. 3. Lab-to-fab transfer for enabling technologies and pilot lines. RTOs and EU pilot lines develop advanced technologies but often lack a stable industrial endpoint. TRF is conceived as an industrial layer on top: it does not replace pilot lines but offers a manufacturing-grade environment with clear quality and audit requirements for transitioning mature modules. 4. An open but industrial-ready design and EDA ecosystem. Access to design tools, fabrication and test remains a barrier for many SMEs. TRF addresses this through open PDKs, harmonised design kits and fair MPW/small-series schemes that lower entry barriers while remaining compatible with industrial qualification. The attached Executive Summary and Q&A explain how TRF complements RTOs and EU initiatives, why we propose a phased 130 nm 65 nm strategy with 130 nm as reference node, how a brownfield-first, ESG-conscious implementation can reduce risk and time-to-impact, and how the model is designed as a network of sites built from the same cloneable reference-fab blueprint rather than a single flagship fab. On this basis we recommend that Chips Act 2 (i) explicitly recognise trustworthy mature-node reference fabs with integrated test and assembly as strategic manufacturing infrastructure, (ii) open dedicated instruments for open, cloneable reference fabs that commit to open PDKs and SME-oriented access models, and (iii) link Pillar 3 monitoring to trustworthy manufacturing capacity by defining criteria for such reference fabs and integrating them into crisis and defence monitoring.

feedback: Advanced, consolidated and aligned conttribution from Forschungszentrum Juelich GmbH (FZJ) as clarification to the first statement: Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH (FZJ) welcomes the initiative of the European Commission to review the Chips Act and to launch an ambitious Chips Act 2.0. As a member of the Helmholtz Association with some 7,600 employees, we conduct interdisciplinary research into a digitalized society, a climate-friendly energy system, and a sustainable economy. We combine our expertise in high-performance computing and artificial intelligence using unique scientific infrastructures. Currently, all AI activities are based on the same technical principles, primarily utilizing GPUs. From a systems perspective, this approach is highly power-consuming and inefficient, and it is expected that only incremental evolutionary improvements will be achieved in the future. For the next generation of AI, it is essential to give greater attention to the emerging principles already present in scientific research, including the utilization of novel devices, such as those based on neuromorphic computing. These principles open the potential for revolutionary AI implementations with significantly reduced power consumption. However, this shift also necessitates a highly specialized co-design approach, encompassing everything from application and training to algorithms, implementations, and specific technologies. Currently, these efforts are primarily driven by the scientific community, yet it is crucial that they are adequately represented in future European initiatives like ChipsJU to ensure European sovereignty in this field. To achieve this, the following measures are necessary (without claiming to be exhaustive): 1. Accessible and cost-effective access to pilot lines with feature sizes below 10nm to make these technologies economically viable for companies. 2. Integration of emerging devices (e.g., memristors, ferroelectric transistors, etc.) into pilot line processes. 3. Seamless transfer of experimental devices into established pilot lines. 4. Development of process design kits (PDKs) tailored to such emerging devices. 5. Design of functional libraries that provide key functionalities with these devices for use in pilot lines. 6. Enhancement of development workflows to support these devices. 7. Development of co-design workflows that integrate both hardware and software considerations. These actions should lead to more extensive, particularly hardware-related, research and transfer of future AI principles. These actions are in no way intended to compete with the ongoing quantum computing efforts within the EU. Rather, they should be viewed as complementary, with the goal of leveraging Europe's strengths in adopting innovative concepts, as opposed to relying on traditional 'brute force' scaling methods. Quantum chip design and manufacturing are essential to the EUs technological sovereignty. The first Chips Act successfully launched pilot lines for quantum chips, laying the groundwork for competitive European capabilities in this strategic area. As the European Commission prepares the upcoming Quantum Act, it is crucial that Chips Act 2.0 both reinforces and complements these initiatives, creating a coherent framework that accelerates quantum-hardware development from research through to industrialization. Strengthening the EUs capacity to design, prototype, and manufacture quantum chips will be critical for securing leadership in this strategic domain and safeguarding the EUs strategic autonomy.

feedback: Including PCB production and population in the European Chips Act 2.0 is important to increase technological independence. Chips alone do not create functional systems; reliable PCB and board population with electronic components is an important step to produce reliable functional systems. Today, Europe relies heavily on Asian assembly for high volume products. Challenges to the PCB technological evolution and PCB population are driven by dedicated high pin-count devices (e.g. µ-vias, multiple layer stackings, heat dissipation, coating) and require highly specialized board population processes (temperature profiles, solder alloys, soldering techniques). Relying with respect to these crucial process on non-European sources leaves strategic sectors exposed to supply chain disruptions and geopolitical risks. By enhancing PCB and EMS capabilities, Europe can secure its entire electronics value chain and strengthen resilience. This capability is vital for space applications, where satellites demand high-reliability PCBs and EMS processes. It is also crucial for defense systems, ensuring operational sovereignty and preventing foreign interference in mission-critical technologies. Furthermore, domestic PCB and EMS enhances data security by reducing risks of hardware-level tampering and supports compliance with EU cybersecurity and privacy standards. Beyond security, investing in PCB and EMS drives economic growth, creates high-tech jobs and accelerates innovation in aerospace, automotive and other sectors. It maximizes the return on semiconductor investments by completing the ecosystem from chip to board. Localized production also supports Europes sustainability goals by lowering carbon emissions associated with global supply chains and enabling greener manufacturing practices. For Europe to maintain leadership in space, defense and critical infrastructure, PCB and EMS is recommended to be included in funding, standards development and collaborative initiatives under Chips Act 2.0.

feedback: The European Chips Act is a highly valuable initiative, and its continuation, expansion, and reinforcement are indispensable. The structural gaps that Europe faces across the semiconductor value chain cannot be closed within only a few years; addressing them requires sustained, long-term programs that ensure continuity, predictability, and stability. It is very important that these programs remain inclusive in scope, engaging all actors capable of contributing to the shared objective of strengthening the European Unions competitiveness in the strategically vital domain of microelectronics. As a research and technology organization developing complex instrumentation for fundamental science and related applications, we would like to highlight two specific areas where further emphasis would generate significant impact. The first concerns the development of integrated electronics and systems designed to operate in extreme environmentsspecifically, temperatures well outside the conventional 40 °C to +125 °C range and/or high-radiation conditions. Such specialized circuits are essential for state-of-the-art scientific instrumentation, including accelerator-based experiments, neutrino and dark-matter detectors, and large astroparticle observatories, all of which depend on custom high-performance integrated systems capable of maintaining stability and precision under challenging conditions. Similar requirements arise in several other strategic domains: emerging fields such as quantum technologies and fusion-reactor diagnostics; rapidly expanding sectors such as space exploration and Earth-observation systems; and consolidated industries, including automotive. Electronics for extreme environments therefore represent an area in which the EU still holds a significant opportunity to achieve international leadership within a relatively short timeframe. However, the reliable design of CMOS-based integrated circuits for such environments is currently hindered by several technical and structural barriers. These include the limited availability of foundry models and digital libraries characterized for extreme temperatures or high-radiation operation, as well as the shortage of more complex reusable IP blockssuch as high-resolution data converters, phase-locked loops, timing circuits, and digital signal-processing coresspecifically adapted to harsh-environment constraints. Addressing these gaps would substantially accelerate innovation across scientific, industrial, and emerging markets and would constitute the naturaland necessarycomplement to the important efforts already underway in wide-bandgap semiconductor technologies. The second key point is the persistent shortage of skilled professionals across the semiconductor ecosystem, and particularly in integrated-circuit design. Efforts to attract, educate, and retain talent must be further intensified, with special attention to mechanisms that effectively bridge the gap between academic training and industrial practice. Such mechanisms are especially valuable for small and medium-sized enterprises, which often lack the resources and risk-tolerance needed to train new personnel independently. In this context, organizations capable of providing practical, realistic use casesand that are inherently more resilient to the risks associated with involving in-training personnel in advanced projectscan play a pivotal role. By offering hands-on experience across full design cycles, these organizations can significantly accelerate workforce development, strengthen Europes semiconductor capabilities, and ensure that the objectives of the European Chips Act translate into long-term, sustainable impact.

Reconocer la fotónica y las tecnologías III-V como pilar central de la autonomía estratégica, con un programa específico para crear y fortalecer una red europea de open-access foundries fotónicas e híbridas. (4). Strengthen talent and skills along the value chain, supporting regional nodes where there is already concentration of universities, technology and industry in photonics and communications. (5). Create a specific European category of open-access specialised Foundry for critical technologies (photonics, III-V, power, advanced sensors), with its own State aid framework and priority access to European instruments. (6). Stimulate demand through innovative public procurement and long-term capacity contracts, so that projects funded by other European programmes prioritise the use of European Foundries, providing demand visibility and strengthening the Union’s security of supply.

feedback: Europes semiconductor ecosystem remains constrained by limited design access, fragmented state-aid procedures, workforce shortages, and the absence of sustainability-aligned incentives. While the 2023 Chips Act was an essential foundation, its implementation has shown structural gaps. SMEs and universities still lack affordable access to design tools, IP libraries, and pilot lines; permitting for semiconductor projects remains inconsistent and slow across Member States; new facilities face talent shortages; and environmental considerations remain insufficiently integrated. As a result, Europe risks missing its goal of strengthening resilience and competitiveness across the semiconductor value chain. A revised Chips Act 2.0 should shift focus from manufacturing volume toward ecosystem capacity. I propose a framework built around four pillars. First, the Act should establish an EU Open Chip Platform providing open-source EDA tools, shared IP blocks, and accessible pilot-line capacity. Reserving a share of public pilot-line time for SMEs and research institutions would broaden participation and unlock innovation beyond large incumbents. Second, a unified EU coordination portal should streamline state-aid approvals, environmental permitting, and grid-access processes. Introducing binding timelines and transparent dashboards would reduce delays that currently discourage private investment. Third, the Act should create a talent-mobility and workforce program including semiconductor-specific vocational pathways, a harmonized curriculum, and facilitated mobility for engineers across Member States. Without a skilled workforce, new R&D capacity and fabrication facilities cannot operate at scale. Fourth, sustainability-linked incentives should be incorporated by tying state-aid intensity to low-carbon energy use and resource-efficient production. Aligning semiconductor expansion with the European Green Deal strengthens Europes long-term competitiveness and attracts companies seeking low-carbon supply chains. These four pillars directly address the shortcomings of Chips Act 1.0. Open design access resolves the current concentration of design capability among a few large firms. A unified coordination portal removes fragmentation that delayed several major investment projects. Workforce programs mitigate the talent shortages that have limited operational readiness. Sustainability incentives ensure that semiconductor scaling is environmentally and economically viable in Europes regulatory context. Together, these reforms transform the Chips Act from a fabrication-centric intervention into a coherent ecosystem strategy. Concerns about centralization, cost, or competitiveness can be mitigated. The proposed coordination portal preserves Member State authority while simplifying procedures. Open-source design tools complement, not replace, proprietary systems. Sustainability incentives reward efficient production rather than impose burdens. And allocating a portion of pilot-line access to SMEs enables innovation without restricting industrial deployment. Chips Act 2.0 can therefore enhance Europes semiconductor resilience, broaden participation, and ensure that public investment delivers long-term strategic benefit.

feedback: A comprehensive EU semiconductor strategy has to pave the way to support holistic semiconductor ecosystem development and support upstream supply chain components like fabless business models, design, packaging, and test. This avoids ecosystem fragmentation and strengthens supply chain security. feedbackTextUserLanguage: The European Union, through the European Chips Act, aims to strengthen domestic semiconductor production capacity, but real sovereignty in an industrial sector is achieved through supremacy and control over design. The design of semiconductor devices is extremely important because it enables the creation of microelectronic components based on open, transparent and verifiable architectures, capable of ensuring high standards of hardware security, reliability of validation processes and technological autonomy along the entire value chain. Requirements of this nature are particularly critical in strategic areas such as edge computing, Internet of Things (IoT), critical infrastructure and digital platforms of national relevance. This concept could be misled by thinking only about the design of semiconductor microelectronic devices, a sector where Europe is currently at a high global level. Achieving real European technological sovereignty therefore requires systemic action, going beyond the mere expansion of manufacturing capacities. It requires the construction of an integrated ecosystem including: advanced training and skills development programmes, coordinated and long-term industrial policies, significant investment in fundamental and applied research, structured mechanisms for transnational cooperation, and a regulatory framework conducive to sustainable, secure and competitive growth in the semiconductor industry. A number of initiatives have been taken since the current programme to coordinate the ecosystem. The new measure should add value to the entire production chain, focusing in particular on the sectors with the greatest scope for growth and added value in order to increase competitiveness in the medium and long term. Taking into account the semiconductor production chain, with the exception of the raw materials sector, where there are major shortages in Europe, the sector of design and manufacture of production and testing machinery is the one where Europe is the world leader. The wafer manufacturing sector is fully automated and controlled by production machines. If we combine this natural talent from the old continent with the growing need to integrate heterogeneous semiconductors, we should aim to strengthen the technology sector for back-end technology. The backend intended for the heterogeneous allintegration of various semiconductors, which is currently undergoing significant expansion, requires a scientific and technological effort aimed at creating integrated circuits (system packages) directly at day level, overcoming the traditional PCB-based paradigm. This approach, which has long been adopted by the main global industrial players for large-scale products, is intended to generate significant competitive advantages in areas such as defence, security, automotive and, in particular, industrial automation and robotics. In the second phase of the EU Chips Act, Heterogeneous Integration should be thoroughly analysed and an effective financial policy applied, going beyond the concept of first of a kind, in support of already active public and private initiatives with the aim of acquiring the know-how needed to regain an international competitive advantage and to have control over the entire value chain.

feedback: The objective of the European Chip Act reflects a strong desire to strengthen the independence of Europe's electronics industry. Within this value chain, the PCB is one of the most critical links. This product, which defines all the electrical connections that link each chip and component, embodies a significant portion of the expertise of design offices. Each PCB is linked to a single function, and therefore, even though PCB factories employ only 14,000 people in Europe, they are directly connected to all electronics design offices. We are beginning to see significant growth in Asia in the supply of pre-wired printed circuit boards (PCBs + PCBAs), suggesting an increase in the added value of electronic functions. This strategy, which we've seen in the telephony and solar panel sectors (now almost entirely manufactured in Asia), risks being repeated. The difference will be that we'll be dealing with sectors such as our defense, healthcare, and mobility electronics industries. It is imperative to integrate PCBs and PCBAs into the European Chip Act 2 if we don't want to miss the objective of strengthening our electronic independence.

feedback: The feedforward for the upcoming revision of the CHIPS Act is articulated in 7 policy focus points, to be linked to the European Semiconductors Regions Alliance paper, attached, which was adopted by the ESRA political network in July 2025. Insofar as possible, policies designed should identify how to best make use of the regional dimension as a multiplier and a facilitator of european level policies, leveraging the capillarity and close connection to regional stakeholders and "small"/"smaller" actors, thereby bringing into view a holistic integration of the whole European value chain and overcome geographical, policy and financing fragmentation. 1. Strengthen Pre-Commercial Procurement with Regional Integration: - Advocate for EU-level mechanisms that prioritize innovative public procurement to accelerate adoption of European semiconductor technologies. - Link procurement to regional specializations by mapping technologies developed in EU territories that can serve strategic projects (e.g., AI giga-factories, critical infrastructures). - Foster, even at the risk of hindering or slowing pan-European deployment, conditionality in public procurement: introduce or reinforce minimum thresholds for EU-origin technology to stimulate demand for European SMEs and startups. 2. Reinforce the Entire Semiconductor Value Chain: - Support industrial segments beyond chip manufacturing, including equipment suppliers and technology adopters (AI, automotive, quantum, photonics). - Develop financial instruments to help user industries absorb higher costs of EU technologies compared to non-EU competitors. - Promote lab-to-fab strategies for technology transfer, ensuring R&D results scale to industrial deployment. 3. Enable Interregional Cooperation and Extended Value Chains: - Create a European Competence Map to identify complementarities across regional ecosystems. - Incentivize cross-regional clusters and partnerships to reduce competition and foster joint projects. - Recognize extended value chains in funding criteria (e.g., clusters in neighboring regions should be favored in large-scale investments). 4. Align and Combine Funding Streams: - Establish mechanisms to blend EU, national, and regional funds for strategic projects that cannot rely solely on IPCEI or Chips JU. - Avoid over-dependence on Member State budgets for transformative projects; ensure direct EU contributions for ecosystem-building initiatives. 5. Develop Talent and Mobility Incentives: - Introduce joint training programs with special conditions for semiconductor sectors to make them more attractive. - Promote intra-EU mobility schemes for skilled workers, enabling regions with strong academic capacity to benefit from workforce circulation. - Offer incentives for companies participating in collaborative training and reskilling programs. 6. Integrate Semiconductor Policy with Complementary Tech Strategies: - Ensure legislative coherence between semiconductor policies and those for AI, quantum, photonics, and automotive, given their interdependence. 7. Accelerate Technology Transfer: - Implement a robust technology transfer policy to move innovations from lab to fab, beyond pilot lines. - Support industrial-scale deployment through targeted, diversified funding and regulatory facilitation.

feedback: Kalray welcomes the European Commissions initiative to revise the Chips Act. Adopted in September 2023 to address semiconductor shortages, the Chips Act must now evolve to reflect a transformed market, rapid technological shifts, and new geopolitical realities. While the ambition to secure a 20% EU market share by 2030 is both commendable and necessary, the current framework could better support the key players best positioned to realize it: fabless innovators like Kalray, which have been at the forefront of the AI chip domaina segment critical to meeting Europes targets. Our experience highlights some of the challenges in this endeavor. As an early and active contributor to policy discussions, we have engaged constructively with European and national decision-makers, yet we have encountered structural obstacles: Exclusion from the IPCEIs Sense Pilar on Microelectronics despite our strategic alignment, with limited transparency in the criteria underlying the selection decisions. A misalignment with the EIC, where our roadmap, focused on cutting-edge AI hardware, was not fully recognized as a 'priority' or 'strategic' initiative, which seems inconsistent with the EUs broader objectives. Ongoing hurdles in fundraising, as venture capital remains cautious about scaling deep-tech companies, and public funding has traditionally favored traditional fabs on mature nodes, which may not fully align with emerging market needs like AI. Complexities in the allocation process for EU funds, where navigating administrative requirements can sometimes overshadow core business priorities. These challenges reveal a significant gap between the Chips Acts ambitious goals and the practical support needed to achieve themespecially for the fabless and design ecosystems that are critical to Europes competitiveness in advanced semiconductor technologies. Yet, these innovatorswho will drive demand for cutting-edge nodes and then attract major manufacturers like TSMC, Intel, or Samsunghave received disproportionately little attention compared to traditional semiconductor factories. Europes capacity for advanced FinFET nodes (5nm and beyond) remains underdeveloped, and fostering their customer ecosystem is crucial to changing this dynamic. Fabless companies like Kalray, with their agile, innovation-driven models, represent one of Europes strongest assets for reducing dependencies, diversifying supply chains, and capturing high-growth opportunities. With enhanced support, they can fully contribute to Europes semiconductor sovereignty. This contribution aims to propose actionable recommendations to better integrate fabless ecosystems into a revised framework, ensuring the Chips Acts success. Recommendation 1: Formally recognize fabless companies as the cornerstone of a sovereign semiconductor ecosystem, with policies tailored to their distinct needs across the value chain. Recommendation 2: Provide targeted R&D supportthrough subsidies, tax incentives, or matched fundingto European fabless companies, particularly innovative SMEs, enabling them to develop sovereign design capabilities and secure a greater share of the value chain, in line with the Draghi reports recommendations. Recommendation 3 (inspired by the Draghi report and aligned with Eurostack): Establish procurement preferences for EU-produced chips in public data centers and HPC infrastructures, ensuring that public investments translate into sustainable market opportunities for European companies and reinforce the continents strategic autonomy in AI hardware. Recommendation 4: Launch an IPCEI dedicated to chiplet technologies, with a dual focus on: 1. Creating a European chiplet ecosystemincluding standardized interfaces, shared design tools, and a network of trusted assembly partnersto enable fabless companies to compete in global markets. 2. Tying public funding to measurable collaboration metrics, such as joint patents, shared roadmaps, or consortia-based projects

feedback: Joint recommendations of the SILICON ALPS Cluster, representing over 140 Austrian semiconductor stakeholders67% of them start-ups and SMEsfor the European Chips Act 2.0. The recommendations focus on strengthening Europes semiconductor competitiveness by addressing structural gaps, empowering innovation-driven SMEs, and expanding Europes technological and industrial sovereignty. Austrias semiconductor ecosystem combines strong design expertise, emerging fabless companies, advanced research institutions, and a growing talent base. To fully leverage this potential, Chips Act 2.0 must provide simplified access to funding, foster demand for European technologies, reduce supply-chain vulnerabilities, and support a coordinated pan-European skills and innovation framework. Key objectives include reinforcing Europes global competitiveness through balanced support across design, manufacturing, materials, and packaging; supporting the strategic value of the European fabless model; improving private capital mobilization; and broadening the semiconductor value chain to passive components, equipment, packaging, and system integration. Start-ups and SMEs require targeted support to translate technological innovation into market-ready products. Priority measures include strengthened accelerators, subsidized access to advanced design and prototyping tools, open-source PDKs and RISC-V technologies, tape-out co-funding, and shared test and validation infrastructure. Such instruments will accelerate time-to-market, reduce development risks, and stimulate entrepreneurial growth. To close Europes skills gap, the cluster recommends merging existing educational initiativesincluding GreenChips-EDU, Unite!, and TRANSFORMinto a pan-European Knowledge and Innovation Community (KIC Chips). A microcredentials framework should support lifelong learning, labour mobility, and transparent recognition of semiconductor-relevant skills. Regulatory complexity remains a major barrier for SMEs. Enhanced state-aid schemes, simplified fast-track applications, cascade funding, regulatory sandboxes, and clearer long-term guidance are needed to improve access and reduce administrative burdens. The European Competitiveness Fund should implement SME-friendly financing instruments, including equity matching, milestone-based co-investment, revenue-sharing models, tax incentives, and support for capital-intensive hardware development. Stronger governance and coordination are essential. Regional clusters should be integrated directly into decision-making bodies such as the Chips Joint Undertaking and the European Semiconductor Regions Alliance. Demand-side incentivesespecially in automotive, energy, telecommunications, healthcare, and defenceshould stimulate early adoption of European chips through procurement frameworks and co-development programmes. Strategic opportunities for Europe include integrated photonics, edge AI, sustainable AI hardware, RISC-V, critical materials, equipment development, packaging, and substrates. Accelerated standardization processes and harmonized permitting procedures are crucial to lowering market-entry barriers and reducing delays in scaling production capacity. Overall, the recommendations call for a coherent, SME-centred Chips Act 2.0 that builds on regional strengths, improves Europes innovation-to-market capabilities, and transforms semiconductor research excellence into sustainable industrial leadership.

feedback: European Union should take a strategic, long-term approach in revising the Chips Act by prioritizing investments in chip design competence, reinforcing existing pilot lines, and ensuring sustainable funding for research and education. The foundation of a resilient semiconductor ecosystem begins with design. Manufacturing success depends on a strong base of skilled designers and design companies, especially in fabless models where design is decoupled from fabrication. Europes competitive edge lies in its application domain expertise. To maintain and grow this advantage, the EU must invest in design competence first. Without a robust design ecosystem, investments in advanced CMOS manufacturing facilities are premature and risky. The EU currently has only a handful of companies designing the most advanced CMOS nodes, with Nokia being one of the few. Building up design capabilities is essential to attract fabless companies and eventually justify large-scale manufacturing investments. Pilot lines established under the first Chips Act must be continuously supported and upgraded. They serve as platforms for innovation, enabling companies to prototype and commercialize new technologies. However, their success depends on ensuring that design companies have the resources and tools to access and utilize them effectively. Bridging the gap between design and manufacturing through improved design kits and integration is critical. On top of that, more European companies should be exploiting own chips in their portfolios. Currently many companies use off-the-shelf components or programmable general-purpose chips manufactured outside EU. To encourage companies to design their own chips, there should be financial support for pilot projects. Successful company pilots with the European pilot lines will show the companies that they can rely on European design competence and manufacturing capability. This is essential for securing the European self-sufficiency in semiconductors. In addition, the EU must place greater emphasis on advanced packaging and system integration. These areas are increasingly central to semiconductor performance, enabling compact, energy-efficient, and high-speed solutions. Packaging and integration are no longer peripheral concernsthey are strategic technologies that determine competitiveness in domains such as AI, communications, automotive, and edge computing. Europe must invest in infrastructure and R&D for heterogeneous integration, chiplet architectures, and photonic interconnects to remain globally relevant. Current funding mechanisms are too short-term and overly focused on immediate industrial needs. Academic research and education, which are vital for long-term competence development, are underfunded and lack strategic support. We call for stable, long-term funding that spans multiple election cycles and supports doctoral programs, competence centers, and academic-industry collaboration. Doctoral education must be rigorous and forward-looking; three-year programs are insufficient for producing the highest level of expertise needed in industrial and academic settings. Europe must also balance its investments between advanced CMOS and specialized technologies such as photonics, RF, MEMS, quantum, and advanced materials. These areas offer significant growth potential and global competitiveness. By supporting both emerging and established sectors, EU can build technological sovereignty and resilience across the semiconductor value chain. Manufacturing capability alone is not sufficient as technology without design tools will be useless. New tools are also essential for unconventional computing paradigms, e.g., quantum and neuromorphic. Advances are also needed to support software/hardware co-design. We advocate for a coordinated European strategy that pools the strengths of different regions and commits to a long-term vision for microelectronics. This enables EU to secure its position in critical sectors.

feedback: As a fully European PCB manufacturer, we want to emphasize a crucial point: Europe needs more than chips. The current Chips Act is an important first step, but it does not sufficiently strengthen Europes overall electronic and system-level resilience. By focusing mainly on front-end semiconductor manufacturing, the Act leaves critical bottlenecks in the back end of the electronics supply chain unresolvedthereby increasing Europes dependency on third countries. This poses concrete risks for defence, automotive, industrial automation, AI data centers, and other strategic sectors. Chips alone do not create functionality. They become operational only when integrated through conductive structures on printed circuit boards (PCBs) and assembled into PCBA modules and full systems. These layersPCB and PCBA production, packaging, and system integrationare strategic choke points. Addressing them is essential for maintaining Europes technological leadership and sovereignty. Additionally, Europe risks losing vital expertise. PCB technology is highly complex; deep competence cannot be developed through academic training alone but requires many years of industrial experience. PCBs and electronic assemblies are also susceptible to technical manipulation, as demonstrated in several studies (e.g., PANDA). Our recommendation is clear: Europe needs a Chips Act Plus that covers the entire electronics value chain. Specifically, we propose: Expanding the scope from silicon to complete systems: explicitly recognising PCB and PCBA manufacturing as strategic priorities, supported by dedicated funding instruments. Creating targeted incentives to strengthen European PCB and PCBA capacities, including minimum European content requirements and public support for building and maintaining production capabilities. Requiring PCBs that are manufactured and assembled in Europe for all safety- and security-critical applications and infrastructures not only to reduce strategic dependencies, but also to safeguard the essential industrial know-how that would otherwise be lost. In summary: Europe must take a holistic approachinvesting from chip fabs to end systems, from silicon and advanced packaging to PCB/PCBA manufacturingto secure technological resilience, sovereignty, and competitiveness. A Chips Act Plus is essential to achieve this.
