feedback: IG Metall welcomes the European Commissions initiative to review the European Chips Act. As Europes largest union representing workers in manufacturing and R&D, including semiconductors and microelectronics, we stress that the revision must go beyond strengthening Europes technological sovereignty. It should also create quality jobs and uphold social and environmental standards. The call for evidence rightly emphasizes reducing EU dependency and enhancing manufacturing capacity. The revised Chips Act should more explicitly promote establishment of as many production steps as possible within the EU, not just for leading-edge chips. The preservation and creation of quality employment must be an explicit objective. Europe has already witnessed the near-complete disappearance of PCB manufacturing and decline in backend semiconductor fabrication (assembly, packaging, testing). This trend must be reversed, as resilience cannot be achieved without a certain degree of all parts of the semiconductor production chain in Europe. Achieving this is feasible with the right kind of policy support, as all aspects of semiconductor production can be competitively done in the EU. With the shift to advanced packaging, backend production has become less dependent on low labour costs, which traditionally fuelled offshoring. We welcome that the Chips Act allows member state subsidies for first-of-a-kind semiconductor manufacturing facilities in the EU. We note positively that this definition includes leading-edge and legacy frontend production, semiconductor equipment, and backend production. We suggest further broadening this to include PCB manufacturing and semiconductor materials production. It should also cover frontend and backend manufacturing that is not first-of-a-kind in the EU but reduces dependence on production in non-EU countries. Such dependence must be reduced for all parts of the semiconductor production chain and for all types of semiconductors, not just leading-edge chips. Most importantly, we call for funding under the revised Chips Act to be explicitly linked to employment commitments, including minimum numbers of jobs to be created and maintained over a defined period with provisions for repayment of subsidies if commitments are not met. Public funding must be conditioned on robust social standards: Job security commitments with binding employment levels over defined durations Collective bargaining agreements with recognized trade unions Worker representation through works councils and equivalent structures These requirements are essential, not only because working in cleanroom environments is physically and mentally demanding. Effective worker representation is necessary to develop tailored solutions with management that protect worker health, promote qualification as well as vocational training and ensure decent working conditions. The revised Chips Act should ensure that funding mechanisms are more accessible to small and medium-sized enterprises, supporting a diverse and resilient semiconductor ecosystem. If their projects are not suitable to be considered for support under Pillar 2 of the Chips Act, there should be clear mechanisms to refer them to relevant funding mechanisms. The call for evidence notes support for sustainable production facilities. IG Metall calls for concrete environmental criteria attached to funding decisions: Resource-efficient production using renewable energy Development of processes to avoid or minimize PFAS usage Water recycling and recovery systems In conclusion, the revision presents a critical opportunity to build a European semiconductor industry that is technologically advanced, economically resilient, socially just, and environmentally sustainable. feedback: Europes ambition to restore its technological sovereignty in semiconductors requires addressing not only chip production itself, but the entire value chain that enables electronics production. Our company is involved in the development, manufacturing and supply of materials of soldering, sintering, cleaning, cooling and protecting for the assembly of semiconductor, and electronic circuit. Those materials are indispensable to front-end, back-end and electronics manufacturing as they are used across strategic industries such as aerospace, AI, defence, energy, medical, mobility and telecommunications. The first Chips Act marked a decisive step, yet it overlooked several strategic links: advanced chemical materials, interconnection, assembly, cleaning, cooling and coating essential processes without which the semiconductor and industrial reliability standards of end markets cannot be achieved. This value chain is today fragmented and heavily dependent on non-European suppliers, especially in chemicals and metallurgy. Securing European chip manufacturing while leaving these segments exposed would continue to weaken the resilience of the whole ecosystem. The shift toward wide-bandgap semiconductors reinforces this need. These new materials operate under harsher electrical and thermal conditions, requiring interconnection solutions with excellent conductivity, heat dissipation and high-temperature resistance. Strengthening European capabilities in these domains is therefore a prerequisite for competitiveness in next-generation power electronics. Cleaning and cooling processes are equally critical. Cleaning ensures surface integrity at every stage of chip fabrication, especially after etching, while cooling dissipates the extreme heat generated during patterning. Historically based on PFAS, these processes now face major regulatory scrutiny. Supporting European companies in developing PFAS-free, recyclable and low-impact alternatives would significantly reduce the environmental footprint of semiconductor production while positioning Europe ahead of tightening global regulations. To achieve these goals, the Chips Act 2 should actively support R&D, industrial deployment and qualification of advanced materials and processes from low-TRL research to pilot lines and full-scale manufacturing. This includes promoting stronger collaboration between local industries, RTOs, public research, start-ups, SMEs and mid-caps, particularly in design, advanced chemistry, assembly and thermal management. Europe already hosts high-performing players in these areas, but they remain insufficiently connected and often overlooked compared to large manufacturers. Technological sovereignty cannot be achieved through isolated flagship fabs alone. It requires an integrated and sustainable ecosystem in which each link materials, equipment, design, interconnection, assembly, cleaning and cooling is recognized, supported and financed. Extending the Chips Act 2 to these segments would send a strong signal: Europe intends to invest where reliability, safety, sustainability and competitiveness truly begin

feedback: Bavaria is one of Europes most important semiconductor regions, with a focus on chip design, and is also a strong user location. A revised version of the European Chips Act (ECA) is expressly welcomed; however, the following points should be taken into account: ECA 2.0 should address the entire value chainfrom materials and chip design (including tools for chip design) to the printed circuit board. The first of a kind criterion partly prevents an effective strengthening of resilience. In the interest of our user industries, building additional capacities for legacy chips is particularly important. Therefore, for investment projects of special strategic importance, transparent, operational criteria should be defined in place of first of a kind. Considering recent experiences with NEXPERIA, it is also proposed that the backend - especially Advanced Packaging - be given significantly higher priority within ECA 2.0. Given the strategic importance of this issue, it is recommended that the European Union provide substantially more funding in the next financial framework. However, the focus should not solely be on improving supply through the highest possible subsidies. It is also about strengthening the demand side so that producing the relevant chips in Europe becomes profitable for companies. Simply postulating Buy European or linking it to subsidies does not appear promising if consumers are not willing to accept the associated risk premium in the final price. One possible approach could be a substantial expansion of data center capacities. It is proposed that potential European user industries, which as consumers of semiconductors form the backbone of our industrial base and whose needs in some cases vary greatly, be explicitly included in the objectives of ECA 2.0. and, where appropriate, prioritized (funding rate, speed). Particular mention should be made of the security and defense industry, for which secure and trusted supply chains (trusted electronics) are of especially high importance. Even if production volumes are often lower, the defense policy relevance is enormous. In addition, a successful energy transition with sustainable expansion of renewable energy increasingly requires intelligent control through specialized chips for grids. SMEs and innovative Start-Ups should receive special support regarding funding levels and assistance with the highly complex funding procedures. At the same time, the speed of the application process is crucial for the investment planning of applicant companies. A fast-track procedure should therefore be established at the European Commission. Furthermore, it is requested that regions be explicitly involved in ECA 2.0, as they are in direct contact with relevant companies and often contribute significantly to financing through co-funding. Explicit reference is made here to the position paper of the European Semiconductor Regions Alliance (ESRA) from July 2025. The microelectronics sector suffers from a shortage of skilled workers, which, according to numerous studies, will intensify significantly in the coming years. It therefore seems sensible that quantitative and qualitative measures to ensure the skilled workforce become a dedicated pillar of the ECA. Given the complexity, ECA 2.0 cannot actively address all relevant areas. However, it is suggested that (institutionalized) interfaces with other policy fields - such as securing rare earth elements - be explicitly included.

feedback: There is no doubt that Europe must strengthen its competitiveness in the semiconductor sector significantly decrease its dependencies on chips required for system-relevant industries in Europe like automotive, mechanical engineering or others. As mentioned in the VDE-position paper "Hidden electronics IV", it is highly recommended to strengthen the entire semiconductor system across the entire value chain. Europe must close existing gaps and prioritize support for those areas where expertise has been lost. This includes explicitly semiconductor materials as prerequisite for chip production, i.e. bulk crystal growth, wafering, and epitaxial layer deposition should be considered in this context. In addition, upcoming markets should be considered. This will require the development of new and advanced materials and their transition into industrial production. This includes new chip architectures and processing lines, but will also offer Europe a real opportunity to take a leading position. New markets include memristive chips for applications in machine learning & artificial intelligence, advanced high-power electronics for mobility as well as for energy harvesting and storing, as well as chips for quantum computing and communication. While the latter is already addressed through specific initiatives, the design and development of chips for AI and for high-efficiency power electronics should certainly considered a strategic priority. In this context, wide-bandgap materials may become one of the key enabling technologies. Promising emerging materials with large band gaps, such as aluminium nitride (AlN) or gallium oxide (Ga2O3) have already demonstrated their outstanding properties in device prototypes. Other promising materials, especially for memristive devices, are hafnium oxide (HfO2) on silicon or perovskites such as strontium or calcium titanate (SrTiO3, CaTiO3). Europe can build here on existing expertise. Designing and producing new chips cannot be decoupled from advances in materials and materials processing. feedback: Axis Communications began exploring chip design in the late 1980s, developing its first in-house chip, the ARTPEC SoC, in 1999. Chip development has fueled our innovation and growth ever since. As a successful European scale-up, we urge the EU to prioritize the following: 1. Build and retain semiconductor talent in the EU Semiconductor competence is essential for Europes resilience and competitiveness. Europe continues to face talent shortages, the loss of international talent, and a high dependency on non-European expertise. To strengthen long-term capabilities, the EU must support a functioning talent market with cross-border mobility and education aligned with industry needs. The focus should remain on digital system designincluding ASIC and IP developmentwhere Europe already demonstrates strong expertise. Maintaining skills in related areas such as PCB design is also important for sovereignty, but digital system design should stay the strategic priority. 2. Build a European design ecosystem for reusable IP and EDA tools To reduce dependency on non-European actors, the EU should prioritize the development of: - Reusable, EU-developed IP building blocks (e.g., CPUs, NPUs/AI accelerators) - European EDA tools, which are central to every stage of chip development Strengthening European IP and EDA capabilities is a highly cost-efficient way to build resilience and should precede investments in large-scale manufacturing. A coordinated European design ecosystem would accelerate competence building, ensure continuity of key technologies and help semiconductor scale-ups grow within Europe. It would also allow major industrial players to confidently select European providers, increasing overall autonomy in the value chain. 3. Enable high-TRL scale-up collaboration We see a need for a new type of EU structure that enables new innovative technology to be validated in real industrial environments that supports fast industrialization. Europe has many semiconductor research initiatives, but very few commercial scale-ups with proven chip design and mass-market deployment. Axis is one of the rare European companies that has scaled its own ASIC development into global products. Our experience has taught us that validating new innovative technology is crucial. It allows industrial actors to reduce risk and industrialize more quickly, which both are prerequisites for scalability. While Chips Act 1 focused heavily on low-TRL research projects and funding was shattered, Chips Act 2 must focus on deployment-focused, high-TRL pilot projects (close to industrialization). Today, small European innovators struggle to validate new technologies because semiconductor development is expensive, high-risk (and thus difficult to finance) and several areas are dominated by established suppliers. To change this dynamic we urge the EU to in the implementation of Chips Act 2 consider new formats for industrial collaboration where large industrial players act as requirement owners and advisors, academy and smaller companies can test and validate new technology. Such joint ventures would share risk and investment between companies, Member States and academia. While research programs exist today (e.g. Horizon Europe, Chips JU), there are few instruments that support high-TRL industrialization where large industry partners act as requirement owners and validators. This gap prevents European chip innovation from scaling. A flagship initiative could be a jointly specified EU Chip, where several industry partners define common requirements and validate the chip together, making EU technology testable, verifiable and scalable. In addition to technology validation, such industry-driven pilot projects would also improve supply chain transparency and ecosystem visibility, which the Commission identifies as a current gap. Such projects would also give the EU real-time insight into bottlenecks, talent needs and potential strategic dependencies.

feedback: While the Chips Act with its many initiatives has already proven highly beneficial to spur new innovations or kindle tech transfers from academia to industry, as well as maintain critical support infrastructure such as EUROPRACTICE for EDA tools access, a number of areas could profit from further attention. 1) While there has been considerable progress has been made on the processor (mostly RISC-V) as well as AI accelerator side of hardware IP blocks, what is still sorely missing are European (ideally open-source) high-speed I/O blocks for crucial interfaces such as PCI Express and DDR DRAM. As such IP, critical to actually realize computing _systems_, is currently only available from Asian and US suppliers, its lack is a key weakness in European digital sovereignty. 2) The lack of open PDKs for competitive, more modern processes (sub-90nm), preferably for technologies actually fabricated in Europe, is complicating research, education, as well as the entry of innovative SMEs into the market due to the large paperwork effort and long delays associated with getting access to proprietary PDKs. If possible, the Chips Act should provide support to entities creating open-access / open-source PDKs (including complete standard cell libraries), similar to the way Google sponsored creating the open PDK for Skywater 130nm in the US. 3) The current funding scheme of just 70% for academic partners in many of the Chips JU programs makes it very difficult to contribute expertise to the programs. The argument, that the indirect costs can be used to make-up for the underfunding is not generally valid, as in many cases University central admin cashes in these monies, leaving the actual research groups struggling themselves on how to cover the actual costs. This even applies to the JU programs that _do_ cover 100% from the EU side, as national funding organizations tend to still play games with their contribution, which, combined with the tendency of central admin to take a cut of all incoming funds, still leads to underfunding at the researcher level. It would be highly recommended that the EU clarifies to the national partners (and institutional central admin) that 100% means _100% actually available at the researcher level_.

feedback: As a scientific researcher and university educator, I would like to provide a brief analysis in response to the EU Chips Act review consultation [1]. My views are based on four main hypotheses that align with the replies of the European Commission to the European Court of Auditors 12/2025 report [2, 3]. 1.- Chips are not alone. Other technologies, such as computer programming, are necessary for chips to function properly in solving citizens' problems. A significant percentage of the demand for chips is due to the creation or existence of software. Software is what ultimately automates the solution of problems for citizens, companies, institutions, etc. It is also necessary to invest in the software that makes chips work to solve problems. An obvious example is Artificial Intelligence software applications, such as those integrated into autonomous vehicle driving. 2.- More intercontinental cooperation is needed. I believe that the term sovereignty is inappropriate because it distracts from real opportunities. It is unlikely that Europe will achieve absolute independence in the chip supply chain in the short or medium term [2]. Therefore, strategic alliances with other experienced players outside Europe are needed to respond to future chip supply crises. These alliances must be established from the strongest possible strategic position. One way to achieve such a position of strength could be the creation of a European Chip Agency. This agency could not only implement and coordinate the economic management of European investment in chip manufacturing infrastructure but also manage and implement the main strategies for chip research, development, and manufacturing in Europe. It could also play a key role in establishing intercontinental relations with Europe. A precursor to this potential agency could be the Europractice consortium [4], a successor to Eurochip (1989-1995). Europractice already receives funding from the European Union's Chips Joint Undertaking. 3. More services to improve the efficiency of existing chips. Chip manufacturing may not be economically viable in Europe due to insufficient demand to make investments profitable. The limited size and fragmentation of European chip demand across different types of chips means that producing at scale for the European market alone will be very difficult [5]. However, other solutions are possible, such as providing services that optimise the use of new or existing infrastructure in times of shortage. In other words, rather than producing new chips, we could reuse and increase the efficiency of existing ones. For instance, strategies involving refurbishing used chips and providing software services, such as reducing the 'instruction footprint' to optimise their use long after their manufacture date, could alleviate a potential temporary shortage [6]. 4. Fundamental and applied research and training for professionals must be strengthened and guided by the technology industry's demands. Research and training centres should be located closer to industries, rather than the other way around. To this end, industries and Research & Education centres should be concentrated in parts of Europe that have already been named 'technological valleys' [7]. References: [1] DirectorateGeneral for Communications Networks, Call for evidence: Review of the Chips Act (Chips Act 2), 2025. [2] European Court of Auditors, Special report 12/2025: The EUs strategy for microchips. [3] European Commission, Replies of EU to 12/2025 report, 2025. [4] Europractice Consortium, https://www.europractice.com [5] Hancké, Garcia-Calvo, Mister Chips goes to Brussels: On the Pros and Cons of a Semiconductor Policy in the EU. Global Policy, 13, 585593, 2022, https://doi.org/10.1111/1758-5899.13096. [6] Feldstein, Refurbishment gives unwanted electronic devices new lease of life, Natixis, 2024. feedback: My Background: I have been teaching for many years on microelectronics and we have submitted close to 80 different designs over the years in several different technologies, therefore I have been deeply involved in the topic. Access to Chip Design Tools and to Chip Fabrication via Europractice was fundamental for universities to support good and applied teaching in microelectronics, as well as for 'real' chip designs for research projects. In order to help Europe to maintain and improve chip design know-how, it is mandatory to further provide a structure, support and funding for this. Many things went well within Europractice, but the upcoming changes should be used as an opportunity to improve the situation. From my experience, I see at least 4 areas for improvement: 1. The chips submission (tapeout) procedure was often slow, with unnecessary delays, and information exchange was very difficult. A web site where the status of each design can be monitored would improve the situation a lot. Final DRCs were slow by shipping files back and forth by email and by not giving the final DRC decks to end users. This could be streamlined a lot. 2. Running the EDA software required hardware and IT personell for software and design kit installation. Such positions are very difficult to establish and fill at universities so that it can be difficult to maintain a running design infrastructure. A cloud based solution would simplify this A LOT and would give much easier access to more technology options (as they do not need to be installed locally). Also, compute hardware would be more powerful. As heavy hardware is often only required temporarily (for large simulations or checks), it would be much more efficient to share hardware. Cost for this could be partially charged to universities because we save own hardware and personnel. 3. It has been hard or impossible to get technical support on technologies for more tricky questions, because the experts sitting at the vendors are often shielded from University users. A help desk for such questions would improve the situation a lot and avoid unnecessary mistakes. One possibility to implement this is to support university groups, who have deep experience in a particular topic, to act as a help desk for this topic. This would require (limited) financial support and in particular coordination of such expert access. We at Heidelberg could for instance provide support for technologies we know very well. 4. Legal issues (access to software, NDAs for design kits) becomes more and more complicated and a lot of time gets lost with paperwork. While being unavoidable, the rules should be make very clear and as much support as possible should be given, for instance with a centralised collection of NDAs for each person, a mechanism to prolong or cancel NDA etc.

feedback: I welcome the opportunity to provide input to DG CONNECT regarding the ongoing implementation and future evolution of the EU Chips Act. I would like to express strong support for the objectives of the Act and specifically to acknowledge the significant progress already achieved under Pillar 1. The establishment of the EU Pilot Lines will substantially strengthen Europes semiconductor research and innovation ecosystem, enabling advanced prototyping, accelerating technology readiness, and supporting industrial uptake. Likewise, the creation of National Competence Centressuch as Irelands I-C3will deliver essential technical capabilities, training resources, and shared infrastructure that support start-ups and SMEs across the Union. Building on these achievements, a key structural constraint must be addressed to fully realise the impact of the Chips Act: the acute shortage of skilled personnel in integrated circuit (IC) design and semiconductor manufacturing. Despite strong ecosystem growth, the supply of graduates, engineers, and researchers remains significantly below current and projected industrial demand. Given DG CONNECTs mission to strengthen Europes microelectronic leadership, digital autonomy, and support for strategic technologies, resolving this skills gap must be a central priority for the next phase of the Chips Act. Addressing this constraint is also essential to enhance Europes future connectivity and AI capabilities. The following measures are recommended: 1. Strengthening Semiconductor Education Pathways DG CONNECT should support Member States and universities in expanding dedicated IC design and microelectronics pathways within engineering programmes. Recommended measures include: a. Funding to develop focused undergraduate and postgraduate programmes in IC design and semiconductor technology. b. Modernising laboratory and teaching infrastructure. c. Ensuring broad access to state-of-the-art electronic design automation (EDA) tools. d. Providing funding for undergraduate tape-outs to deliver authentic design-to-silicon experience. e. Developing micro-credentials aligned with industry needs. f. Establishing higher-level apprenticeships co-developed by universities and industry partners. These initiatives will significantly improve student preparedness, increase the attractiveness of semiconductor careers, and support DG CONNECTs aims in digital capacity-building and technological sovereignty. 2. Expanding Europes Research and Innovation Base Sustained support for PhD training and postdoctoral research is critical to maintain Europes long-term innovation capacity. Expanded funding streams would: a. Enable research groups to grow and strengthen European semiconductor research. b. Attract and retain global talent. c. Foster multi-disciplinary teams at the intersection of IC design, semiconductor manufacturing, AI applications (cloud, edge, and physical systems), and advanced communications technologies. These capabilities align directly with DG CONNECTs strategic priorities, including next-generation computing, AI hardware, and secure connected systems, and can leverage existing infrastructure such as pilot lines and National Competence Centres. 3. Supporting Talent Retention in the EU Given global competition for semiconductor expertise, DG CONNECT could encourage Member States to consider targeted tax incentives or equivalent retention mechanisms for graduates entering the European semiconductor sector. Such measures would help retain talent and support the sustainable growth of Europes semiconductor workforce. Collectively, these actions will enhance the effectiveness of investments made under Pillar 1, strengthen Europes semiconductor talent pipeline, and ensure long-term strategic autonomy and competitiveness in microelectronics. I thank DG CONNECT for the opportunity to contribute to this consultation and fully support the continuing development of the Chips Act.

Micro- and nanoelectronics provide the technologies that permeate all areas of life and form the backbone of modern societies, all industries, and military defense. The EU Chips Act 1 was a big step forward into the right direction and many industrial investments startet already and are in the realization phase. feedback: The EU can learn from its experience with classical semiconductors, where outsourcing production led to a loss of capabilities. The quantum sector presents an opportunity for Europe to establish itself as a leader and avoid repeating past mistakes. While academic research has been ongoing for decades, commercialization is still in its infancy, and no company has yet fully scaled up production to mature levels. The current focus on building quantum pilot lines for research and development is essential, but it must be accompanied by a clear plan for industrialization at the EU level. Quantum chip fabrication being a novel area of technology, the race is on to ramp it up to mature production level. Quantum, including R&D grade low volume and low integration level chip fabrication, has been a topic of academic research for decades. While the pilot lines which are being built will make the bar lower for start-ups to test their technology, the roadmap of established quantum companies requires production sites. The emergence of quantum chip fabrication presents a global opportunity for regions to establish themselves as production for quantum technology. Europe can capitalize on this trend by creating an attractive environment for quantum companies to set up production sites. To achieve the EU's goal of acquiring systems that can deliver 100 error-corrected qubits by 2030, comprehensive support for chip fabrication is necessary. This plan should focus on establishing a scalable public-private manufacturing infrastructure, with dedicated funding instruments for European startups, scale-ups and SMEs developing quantum chips. A key challenge in quantum chip manufacturing is the transition from laboratory to commercial production. The production of superconducting quantum processors uses traditional semiconductor manufacturing techniques, but with unique materials and structures rendering conventional semiconductor fabrication lines incompliant. To accelerate the transition from laboratory to commercial production, it's essential to have a dedicated set of production tools readily available for start-ups and scale-ups. The Chips Act introduced a series of mechanisms to bolster semiconductor innovation and manufacturing in Europe, notably through Pillar 2. However, Pillar 2 was not designed with the unique requirements of quantum manufacturing in mind, which limits its effectiveness in this emerging domain. While Pillar 2 has laid a foundation for innovation, quantum manufacturing demands a more targeted and faster approach.

feedback: Identifying a Critical Dependency for European Sovereignty Nomenil B.V. is a Dutch technology SME (KvK 98077635) developing a data-driven software platform (N-1) to solve the core process-control bottleneck in Functional Additive Manufacturing (AM). The Problem: The "Artisanal" Bottleneck in Advanced Packaging The review correctly identifies that the EU is dependent on non-EU countries for leading-edge chips (Problem 1) and that "advanced packaging, test and assembly" (Pillar 2) is a key focus. The problem is that these two issues are inseparable. Advanced chips require equally advanced, high-density interconnects and substrates (like PCBs), which cannot be manufactured reliably with current methods. The promise of Additive Manufacturing (e.g., inkjet technology) to deliver this capability has failed, not due to the equipment, but due to the process. The current "artisanal" R&D methoda manual, non-scalable, trial-and-error processis incapable of guaranteeing the required process reproducibility (e.g., 25µm accuracy over large areas). This process failure is the primary innovation bottleneck blocking the EUs strategic sectors (defence, automotive, space) from adopting flexible, localized PCB production. It creates a critical dependency on non-EU supply chains for complex substrates, mirroring the dependency in the chips themselves. Our Contribution: Enabling Pillar 2 and Strengthening the Ecosystem As a European technology provider, our N-1 platform directly addresses this bottleneck. We do not manufacture chips or PCBs; we provide the enabling process knowledge that makes advanced manufacturing scalable and reliable. Enabling Advanced Packaging (Pillar 2): The N-1 platform replaces "artisanal" R&D with a systematic, data-driven calibration framework. It allows manufacturers to generate Digital Correction Profilesa scalable, verifiable form of Process IP. This is the "knowledge in a box" that finally delivers the 25µm accuracy and reliability required for the high-density interconnects that advanced chips depend on. Strengthening Supply Chain Resilience (Pillar 1 & 3): By solving the process bottleneck, our solution enables a secure, decentralized, and flexible European supply chain for advanced PCBs. This is vital for the "strategic sectors" that require low-volume, high-mix, and secure components without relying on non-EU, high-volume fabs. Strengthening the Entire EU Value Chain: The current artisanal support burden is unsustainable, not just for the PCB manufacturers (the "pioneers") but also for the (often European) capital equipment suppliers. Our platform removes this burden, liberating equipment suppliers to focus on innovation rather than costly, non-scalable manual support. Our solution is an ecosystem enabler, turning potential competitors into allies focused on a common goal. Recommendation for "Chips Act 2" Review We urge the Commission to ensure the review and subsequent "Chips Act 2" explicitly recognize that "advanced packaging" and "substrate manufacturing" are fundamental dependencies, not just secondary considerations. The Act must expand its focus to include support for the enabling process technologieslike data-driven calibration and process IP generation frameworksthat unlock this critical part of the value chain. feedback: The European Unions Chips Act has been a pivotal step in fostering semiconductor innovation, enhancing resilience, and securing the future of the regions digital economy. However, for the EU to achieve its goals of technological sovereignty and global competitiveness, it is critical to recognize the interdependent nature of semiconductor manufacturing with other foundational components of modern electronics. Among these, Printed Circuit Boards (PCBs) and Printed Circuit Board Assemblies (PCBAs) play a vital yet often underappreciated role in the broader semiconductor ecosystem. Their inclusion in the Chips Act 2.0 is not only logical but also essential for creating a robust, self-sustaining electronic supply chain within the EU. Incentives for European PCB and PCBA manufacturers should be introduced to encourage local production, reduce costs, and ensure that European companies are not dependent on foreign suppliers for these critical components. Establishing a strong PCB/PCBA manufacturing base is essential for the long-term health of Europes electronics industry. A good example of how local PCB procurement is discouraged today is the current custom duties regulation. The base materials (resin impregnated glass fibers, Copper clads,) needed to manufacture PCBs on EU soil are produced mainly in SEA. The PCB manufacturers need to pay custom duties on these essential base materials ranging between 5 and 7%. PCBs manufactured in China and imported into the EU are exempt from custom duties leading to an unleveled playing field and competitive disadvantage that discourages local EU fabrication of PCB. The defense, space, and aviation sectors are among the most critical industries in the world, involving technologies that are essential to national security, technological leadership, and global competitiveness. At the heart of these technologies are Printed Circuit Boards (PCBs), which serve as the backbone for the electrical systems that power advanced defense equipment, spacecraft, and aerospace vehicles. These industries rely on highly specialized, high-performance PCBs that must meet stringent reliability and safety standards. Given the strategic importance of these sectors, it is crucial that PCBs for defense, space, and aviation applications must be produced within the EU. Doing so is necessary not just for technological and industrial independence, but also to protect critical know-how, security, and innovation. Through the Chips Act 2.0, the EU should also further allocate funds for research into next-generation PCB and PCBA technologies, such as HDI, high-frequency, flexible, and eco-friendly boards. This will allow European manufacturers to lead in the development of innovative solutions that can address future needs in emerging sectors. Beside the capability development through R&D, capacity-oriented initiatives and workforce development initiatives will be essential in order to develop a robust electronic ecosystyem. Only by fully integrating the entire ecosystem (including semiconductors, PCBs, and PCBAs) can Europe truly build a resilient, competitive, and future-proof technological infrastructure for the decades to come.

feedback: The evaluation of the current Chips Act presents an important opportunity to strengthen Europes strategic semiconductor capacity while maintaining democratic governance, transparency, and long-term resilience. Based on my participation in several EU digital-policy consultations, I would offer the following observations. First, the Acts strategic intent is sound, but implementation mechanisms remain uneven. Europe has made progress in research excellence, yet the translation from laboratory outcomes to industrial scale remains fragmented. Public instruments should more clearly support open-access testbeds, shared pilot lines, and interoperable intellectual-property frameworks that allow SMEs and start-ups to participate without disproportionate barriers. Industrial participation needs to be measurable, transparent, and linked to clear technology-readiness milestones. Second, supply-chain security requires a more principle-based and diversified approach. Current dependency patterns in critical materials, equipment, and upstream intellectual property remain a structural vulnerability. The revision should explicitly incorporate multi-region redundancy, trusted-partner verification, and cross-border risk-sharing mechanisms that align with Europes broader quantum, cybersecurity, and space-communication strategies. Coordination with IRIS² and the Quantum Act will be essential for end-to-end secure semiconductor-enabled infrastructure. Third, governance and interoperability require stronger alignment. The Chips Act should avoid parallel, uncoordinated programmes by embedding a coherent oversight structure that brings together Member States, industry, research organisations, and civil society. A periodic review cycletransparent, evidence-based, and linked to emerging riskswould support stable long-term investment conditions while safeguarding democratic accountability. Fourth, talent development remains a decisive bottleneck. Europes long-term competitiveness depends not only on a European Semiconductor Academy but on real mobility: short-cycle reskilling pathways, cross-border fellowships, industrial placements, and coordinated STEM-policy commitments. Talent leakage to non-EU markets will persist unless scale-up pathways are predictable and attractive. Finally, the Acts environmental and energy dimension requires clearer prioritisation. Semiconductor manufacturing is highly resource-intensive. The revision should strengthen circular-economy principles, green-lab standards, and efficient energy-use frameworks while ensuring that sustainability requirements do not inadvertently disadvantage SMEs. In summary, the Chips Act can deliver on Europes ambition if its revision deepens governance coherence, enables industrial participation across the full value chain, and strengthens trusted-partner alignment on resilience and security. I remain available to provide further analysis if helpful.

feedback: TS PCB, a Polish manufacturer of Printed Circuit Boards (PCB), strongly supports the European Unions ambition, articulated within the European Chips Act, to bolster technological sovereignty, security, and resilience in the semiconductor supply chain. The pursuit of enhanced European manufacturing capacity is vital for economic security. However, we must raise a critical and specific concern regarding the scope of the Act: the exclusion of the Printed Circuit Board (PCB) manufacturing sector from its core strategic definitions and support mechanisms. A Technical and Legal Gap in Scope The current framework of the European Chips Act primarily channels support through measures defined under Pillar 2, focusing on the establishment of 'First-of-a-Kind' and 'Integrated Production Facilities (IPFs)' or 'Open EU Foundries (OEFs)'. This core legislative focus defines the scope of strategic support and priority too narrowly. Narrow Definition of 'Integration': By concentrating investment and regulatory efforts almost exclusively on semiconductor fabrication (wafer level) and advanced packaging technologies, the Act fails to account for the crucial interconnection layer necessary to make any chip functional. The PCB is the indispensable physical and electrical foundation that enables the integration of chips into any final electronic system. Exclusion of Critical Enablers: The PCB manufacturing sector, which provides the critical substrate and interconnection technology for all IPFs and OEFs to be practically operationalized, is effectively excluded from these strategic definitions. This creates a literal supply chain gap: we may secure the silicon chip, but if the substrate (the PCB) must still be sourced from vulnerable non-EU supply chains, the goal of true end-to-end resilience is not met. The Threat to Supply Chain Security Ignoring the PCB sector introduces a significant vulnerability that fundamentally undermines the Acts primary objective: Incomplete Resilience: The PCB becomes the unprotected critical bottleneck. Achieving high volumes of European-made chips provides no strategic advantage if their deployment is limited by the availability, quality, and security of corresponding European-made advanced PCB substrates (such as High-Density Interconnect - HDI, and complex multilayer boards). Technological Alignment: Investment in cutting-edge semiconductor nodes requires parallel investment in advanced PCB manufacturing to handle the high density and signal integrity requirements. A gap in the European PCB sector will directly inhibit the effective uptake and integration of the very advanced chips the Act aims to promote. Concrete Recommendation TS PCB urges the European Commission and the co-legislators to formally expand the definitions and scope of support under the European Chips Act 2 to explicitly include the Advanced Printed Circuit Board manufacturing industry. This expansion must ensure that: PCB manufacturing facilities producing advanced substrates are recognized as strategic, 'first-of-a-kind' enablers of the European electronics ecosystem. Funding and regulatory mechanisms are available to stimulate R&D and significant capacity expansion in complex, high-reliability PCB technologies within the EU. A secure European semiconductor supply chain is impossible without a secure, advanced European PCB supply chain. We appeal to the European Commission to close this critical technical and legislative gap.

Catalyse industry-led alliances that connect chip providers with end users to secure early adoption and anchor demand in sectors such as automotive, telecoms and energy. feedbackTextUserLanguage: I cannot get out of the feeling that Chips Act 1 has become a political and academic topic with minimal real outcomes. Despite extensive legislation, the EU’s share of chip production by 2025 has not even increased by 1 % compared to the rest of the world. Backwardness tends to widen. At the same time, support for chip production has been discussed for a relatively long time. According to the Call for Evidence..., the Chips Act, in force since September 2023, has already led to over EUR 80 billion of announced investment in production capacity. This is a relatively large amount, but this has not yet been reflected in the catching-up of Asia or at least the US in this area. Moreover, some of the projects seem to have been delayed or even cancelled. Throughout the legislative and administrative chain, there is a lack of concrete action and targets that are quantifiable and measurable at different points in time. Similarly, there is no definition of responsibility and consequential consequences for non-compliance with the indicators. However, what is no less important is the fact that the chips themselves are unusable without being installed on printed circuit boards (Printed Circuit Boards PCBs). Chips will not fly in the air and their inputs and outputs will not be connected by light conductors. They shall be soldered to a printed circuit board (PCB) where copper conductors ensure that the chips are powered and the outlets (chip contacts) are connected to other electronic components to form a single functional electronic unit. Without quality printed circuits, it is unnecessary to deal with chips themselves. Similarly, the existing Chip Act adopted in the US is followed by a legislative standard known as the PCBs Act, which was submitted to Congress by Blake Moore for approval shortly after the Chip Act was approved. In this way, the Americans realised both the strategic importance of PCBs and the high dependence on the supply of PCBs from China. It is the production of PCBs in a catastrophic state throughout the EU. Still in 2000, there were more than 610 PCB producers in countries that make up the EU today, while in 2025 this number fell to 188 producers. And this is decreasing every year. Therefore, if we do not include in Chip Act 2 the topic of support for PCBs production, our dependence on China for the production of electronics as such will only increase. This applies both to consumer electronics and to electronics intended for strategic military, aerospace, automotive and, for example, the medical industry. For example, the abolition of import duties on basic materials (possibly the introduction of import duties on PCBs imported from the Far East) is very timely. It is also strategically important to legislate that defence and other strategically important products are produced exclusively with European printed circuit boards (PCBs). Or do we want to continue to provide our patented solutions to third countries and Know How by providing them with complete technical documentation for the production, installation and even recovery of PCBs? The Chips Act 2 cannot be a mere political declaration, but must be a very serious topic for expert debate, aiming at outputs that can be applied in practice in the short term so that we are at least left behind, but above all, so that we can achieve the greatest possible autonomy and thus independence from the supply of any electronic components from Asia, at least in defined areas. Politicians as well as the Commission should therefore contact e.g. IPC experts (by way of example, they should already have an office directly in Brussels for this purpose) or, for example, organisations such as ZVEI e.V., the German Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers’ Association, which also has an office in Brussels.

feedback: Photonics is one of the fastest-growing enabling technologies in Europe. In Finland, the photonics industry grows by about 12% annually, and similar rates are seen elsewhere. As electronics approach their physical limits, photonics becomes indispensable: it offers the means to sustain Moores law and overcome Shannons limit, enabling faster, more energy-efficient data transfer and processing. This makes photonics not just supportive, but central to Europes long-term technological sovereignty. Photonics already underpins many strategic sectors. It enables autonomous vehicles, dual-use and defense solutions, advanced healthcare, renewable energy, and quantum technologies. In quantum computing, communication, and sensing, photonics is a core element without which these breakthroughs cannot materialize. Ensuring strong photonics capabilities in Europe is therefore essential to secure competitiveness and resilience in these fields. The current Chips Act pilot lines and facilities provide valuable support for the automotive and mainstream semiconductor sectors. However, the specific needs of photonics are underrepresented. Unlike traditional microelectronics, the photonics sector is largely driven by SMEs and start-ups, often located outside capital regions. Well-known clusters exist in Joensuu (Finland), Jena (Germany), Grenoble (France), and other mid-sized cities. To fully unlock this distributed expertise, pilot lines for photonics should also be geographically distributed. This would ensure that each Member States know-how benefits the whole Union, and that companies can access services close to their ecosystems. There are several critical gaps in existing pilot line coverage that need to be filled: Photonic Integrated Circuits (PICs) for quantum computing, communication, and sensing. Polymers as a cost-efficient and lightweight material platform, especially important for defense. Antimonide (Sb)-based materials for mid-infrared applications, including epitaxy, lasers, and detectors. Glass and specialty fibers for advanced photonic integration, interconnections, and light control. Solution-based solar cells for soft, flexible, and low-cost renewable energy technologies. In addition, Europe must invest in Optical Circuit Boards (OCBs) to manage photons in complex systems. This includes light coupling, transmission, splitting, and modulation, relying on innovative optics (micro/nano-optics, diffractive and freeform optics, meta-optics, 2D materials, waveguides). Such innovations will be vital for hybrid photonicelectronic integration. Photonics devices components that generate, manipulate, or detect light already play a vital role in communications, imaging, energy, security, and healthcare. Their importance will grow further with the rise of quantum technologies, which rely heavily on photonics for functionality. Examples of innovations that could be accelerated with dedicated pilot line support include: High-speed modulators based on thin-film LiNbO3 (TFLN) for hybrid PICs. Smart chip holders introducing standards for full-optical and opto-electronic integration, allowing new levels of signal mixing and material use. Biomedical photonic chips for advanced diagnostics and health monitoring. To remain competitive, the EU must recognize photonics as a core pillar of the semiconductor ecosystem. By creating dedicated and distributed pilot lines, Europe would strengthen its SME-driven innovation base, reduce strategic dependencies, and ensure that photonics continues to power the next generation of semiconductor, quantum, and digital technologies.

feedback: The Chips Act (CA1) could achieve greater impact if it considered a broader spectrum of industry domains in its funding approach. 1. Balanced Industry Coverage :While the automotive sector has rightly been given high priority, other strategically important domains such as AI, Energy, and Robotics also deserve stronger attention. A more balanced allocation would ensure that Europe maintains competitiveness across all critical sectors. 2. Focus of ECS: Calls At present, only one ECS call is dedicated specifically to semiconductors, while the majority address systems, value chains, and pilot-related topics. Increasing the number of semiconductor-focused calls would strengthen the core objective of the Chips Act. 3. Role of RTOs: Significant resources have been allocated to RTOs for technologies that may only reach maturity in 4-7 years, addressing a relatively small portion of the semiconductor market. Furthermore, a considerable share of this funding is consumed by high personnel costs. Introducing reasonable salary caps for professors and researchers could help direct more funds toward technology development and industrial impact. 4. Support for SMEs: SMEs are the backbone of innovation but face a unique challenge: unlike RTOs, which may specialize in one domain of the value chain, SMEs often need to cover the entire spectrumfrom specification, chip design, and PCB development to testing. This requires broad expertise and significant resources. Stronger, tailored support for SMEs is essential, as their survival depends on achieving successful designs; failure or underperformance cannot simply be absorbed as it might be in larger organizations. 5. Expertise and Evaluation: The evaluation/review of CA1 projects could benefit from fresh perspectives. Previous approaches often set unrealistic targets, creating unnecessary risks for smaller participants. A new panel of experts, with meaningful SME representation, would help ensure that targets are both ambitious and achievable. SMEs, who take on the greatest risks, must be adequately represented in decision-making. Meanwhile, larger MNCs, whose focus is often on stock market performance and leadership positioning, should be balanced with input from those driving innovation at the grassroots level. 6. Enhanced Support for Intellectual Property (IP): SMEs should be provided with additional financial support to file patents. This would encourage innovation, strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs, and enable them to better withstand global cost pressures, particularly from countries such as China. (For example, we incurred costs of approximately 29,000 to file patents in Austria and the United States, while the support received was limited to around 6,000. This gap makes it difficult for us to pursue further protection of our innovations. As a result, we are currently discouraged from filing a patent on our breakthrough work in 3D imaging with depth estimation, a technology with significant potential for robotics and machine vision.) 7. Equal Participation in All Projects: SMEs should have the opportunity to participate in every type of project including IPCEI and pilot lines on the same footing as other institutes and organizations. This ensures that their expertise and innovative capacity are fully integrated into the European semiconductor ecosystem. 8. Dedicated Budget Allocation for SMEs: To generate quality jobs and support grassroots innovation, a minimum of 30% of the budget in all EC-funded projects should be allocated to SMEs. For ECS projects, this allocation should be increased to at least 50%. Such measures would ensure that SMEs receive the support necessary to contribute meaningfully while also maintaining a healthy and diverse European innovation landscape.

feedback: I would like to add that it's not just the chips itself but also the PCB's. High-frequency radio hardware requires special, more suitable PCBs, such as electronic warfare systems, 5G systems, phased arrays,... From my understanding only the US and China have such PCB manufacturing at the moment and it has large backlogs to order (6 months). The act probably needs extending to incorporate industries vital to national security. Then, I would urge the EU to consider export restrictions on the latest ASML factory equipment to force the world to build those plants here if they absolutely want the smallest chips. This breeds dependency on EU trade links but also guarantees Europe has the latest technology. For this, those could be added to export restricted materials and export licenses could be denied if no such foundry exists in the EU. This assumes that ASML's technology edge is a defacto monopoly, which I am not sure is the case. As for state-aid, I think the EU should consider developing a sovereign wealth fund like the US is developing now and Norway already has that manages investments at arms-length but can execute mandates given to it by states through subfunds. Having it managed at EU level ensures a level playing field inside Europe and I don't believe we care about outside Europe at this point. The other advantage of this is that revenue from such investments can be recycled in the fund and government capture by industry is mooted as such revenue would not flow into the state budgets again. Such a fund can be an equity investor also, rather than providing grants/subsidies.
